document.title: 2021 Minnesota K12 Academic Standards in Social Studies Final

D20A32F3907D4BDD8A02B4F2BC69B28D.description:
Describe how groups are reviving and maintaining their
traditional cultures, identities and distinctiveness in the context
of increasing globalization.

8233CB153CDD4ACDAD4F2C97262FED6A.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

E1C12AA58E1449EEA66BC35137E383F1.description:
Examine the contributions immigrants in the United States have
made on political ideas, agricultural developments,
technological advancements and cultural traditions.

574E1CC133B34228A013AFF178256425.description:
Resistance: Describe how
individuals and communities have
fought for freedom and liberation
against systemic and coordinated
exercises of power locally and
globally. Identify strategies or
times that have resulted in lasting
change. Organize with others to
engage in activities that could
further the rights and dignity of
all.

2A81FFAEC3D94B47A1DD12A83D860D6C.description:
Examine economic patterns of migration locally and nationally
and explore push-and-pull factors that lead to economic
investment, divestment and destabilization.

3FBE1DCEC1814090AB6D533C71CFD58E.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

7838CB519BD2449E971AA0AE628BDE98.description:
Examine one or more of the major circumstances leading to the
arrival of new immigrants and refugee groups to Minnesota
since the 1950s.

FC8C28CD44704C3DBC4567A8FBE33BD9.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

05D0DFA9576943B78724FEC2A7897806.description:
Examine the cultures and histories of one or more ethnic groups
who have immigrated to Minnesota since the 1950s.

C5F3B2B08EFE4902A487DFC03F15410C.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

DC335D626E054F80A084D97785C216DB.description:
Using historical analysis, predict a future global issue and make
a hypothesis about its impact.

EBA0B663EE8D4A428868C2E40E7C5326.description:
Connecting Past and Present:
Use historical methods and
sources to identify and analyze
the roots of a contemporary
issue. Design a plan to address it.

ACF12D8739C04AF49638007F25ED23EC.description:
Describe how movements, political and social conditions, and
new technologies have affected the lives of women in different
parts of the world since 1950.

B14FA0F398E14647A5E1F34CD541FFB2.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

2B26AEFF99494F478E4A32603D2E8D6D.description:
Describe the development of at least one diasporic community
throughout the world since 1950 due to regional conflicts,
changing international labor demands and/or environmental
factors.

58C98C203046436A98B6599B30FE0A57.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

648769C8A75E47808A317F3E1A466D79.description:
Use primary and secondary sources to analyze how individuals,
groups, and societies around the world have been affected by
genocide, the Holocaust, and mass violence, including
communities resettled in Minnesota.

1F484D58D12744DF9096EE302CF71205.description:
Historical Sources and
Evidence: Investigate a variety of
historical sources by: a) analyzing
primary and secondary sources;
b) identifying perspectives and
narratives that are absent from
the available sources; and c)
interpreting the historical
context, intended audience,
purpose, and author’s point of
view of these sources.

5FDEF48090C0420398265ACDF2608545.description:
Describe varieties of spiritual and religious beliefs and practices
in the contemporary world, including, but not limited to,
Shamanism/Animism, Hinduism, Jainism, Buddhism, Sikhism,
Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Indigenous religious traditions in
Africa and the Americas, and African diasporic religions.

D15DFE0187F24E549AD9FA0059A7D186.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

A45E9056D5D4438096235D0970EC0A4D.description:
Assess the influence of television, the Internet, and other media
on cultural identity, gender identity, and social and political
movements.

99F2A6BA8AF24E01AC5A8CA7C5E40F62.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

8285B103A44A44A28C34F592AA1F5CBE.description:
Analyze connections between revolutions, independence
movements and social transformations since World War II from
various perspectives.

ED10B82B0E86493A88ADA3B183F5DF3F.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

4A6AEB802C7F44EBA044A85834B689CE.description:
Describe causes of economic imbalances and social inequalities
among the world’s peoples in the post-colonial world and
efforts made to close those gaps.

FF5DFE62D59D4C7CBB9D54CC2048B357.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

6AC0324675E04213BD53A5543A0DC4D1.description:
Describe political challenges and struggles of newly
independent countries since World War II.

4910F429770646BD898EAC21D3B8DFF5.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

0396A2D28E9B4C0AB16C339AFEDFB374.description:
Ask and answer questions about how physical and human
characteristics influence one’s sense of place and that of others.

67FB4184F25745C5BD228783C1E2EA21.description:
Culture: Investigate how
sense of place is impacted by
different cultural perspectives.

C798B81C0B5F4B628E0F4BE90AAA4E5B.description:
Ask spatial questions to investigate the relationship between
the environment and human activities and their impact on
climate change.

9D589D775640441092DD5B67F49101A4.description:
Human-Environment
Interaction: Evaluate the
relationship between humans
and the environment, including
climate change.

868BFD8E812745BABC11C58CF2731C3E.description:
Describe urbanization patterns. Analyze a regional example
from both developing and developed regions.

DEFC70BCCD6A4FFF88A696BF3ED3FB3F.description:
Human Systems: Analyze
patterns of movement and
interconnectedness within and
between cultural, economic and
political systems from a local to
global scale.

F395590D404948D58E2EB1EE883C000A.description:
Explain how cultural characteristics influence changes in
population. Analyze a regional example from both developing
and developed regions.

BBBA967ACEEA4578AF31E7F7CF11D042.description:
Human Systems: Analyze
patterns of movement and
interconnectedness within and
between cultural, economic and
political systems from a local to
global scale.

C204590D9938408B954681E4EEBF603E.description:
Explain how distribution of natural resources influences political
systems (societies). Analyze a regional example from both
developing and developed regions.

22900544575D4636BAA4C529A6F6A2C0.description:
Human Systems: Analyze
patterns of movement and
interconnectedness within and
between cultural, economic and
political systems from a local to
global scale.

62A8282530964D3193C2453C8ACEC063.description:
Explain patterns of demographic changes and cultural diffusion
from a local to global scale.

46DA43EC9BE64C71A261A2396DAD03D2.description:
Human Systems: Analyze
patterns of movement and
interconnectedness within and
between cultural, economic and
political systems from a local to
global scale.

AC72A74B3D3443C6AC2880DECF6E193F.description:
Describe regions according to specific criteria and identify the
role of power structures in constructing regions.

158B9D46035B404790BD67BD2858D84C.description:
Places and Regions: Describe
places and regions, explaining
how they are influenced by
power structures.

1B7CC49EA5304D328071247436A6A9D0.description:
Explain how physical and human characteristics influence how
people live in different places.

05E7D1E07E4740F598A8F507C3FBDC0F.description:
Places and Regions: Describe
places and regions, explaining
how they are influenced by
power structures.

FABA6E7FA9674540B3DEB5F646349C56.description:
Apply multiple perspectives to the geographic inquiry process
(ask, acquire, analyze, answer, act) to solve spatial problems.

065A73D1BFA34F80A5FDCDEB26EAFF8A.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

27A318C3A65846A1910A759C9390710E.description:
Use geospatial technologies to create and interpret maps.
Evaluate which geographic tools to apply in different situations.

15832A86EECF45488099A603F191E151.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

9DE895384472414CBDC81D6B2CC8405C.description:
Explain how global trade helps people and countries obtain
goods and services they could not produce (or produce
affordably) for themselves.

C1A2DBFF813A4E2387867E3242EE4FE5.description:
Global and International:
Explain why people trade and
why nations encourage or limit
trade. Analyze the costs and
benefits of international trade
and globalization on communities
and the environment.

4CE2EA47130349A492AF220041812139.description:
Identify factors that affect economic growth (percentage
changes in real gross domestic product [GDP]) and lead to a
different standard of living in different nations and within
nations.

9257F05064DE46858CC589B11F37C894.description:
Macroeconomics: Measure
and evaluate the well-being of
nations and communities using a
variety of indicators. Explain the
causes of economic ups and
downs. Evaluate how
government actions affect a
nation’s economy and
individuals’ well-being within an
economy.

AA90B5A664354DE69F62D69B1AB313AA.description:
Explain how the individual decisions of consumers, producers
and government can impact the whole society in both positive
and negative ways.

092C7634E781477FBC165233D12DBEFF.description:
Microeconomics: Explain and
evaluate how resources are used
and how goods and services are
distributed within different
economic systems. Analyze how
incentives influence the decisions
of consumers, producers, and
governments. Evaluate the
intended and unintended
consequences of these decisions
from multiple perspectives.

F03AF5F5CA1F4938A3DA34ACEC95DB2C.description:
Identify characteristics and goals of traditional, command,
mixed and market-based economies.

EA3A29ABCF9542808668EA0C13B519AC.description:
Fundamental Economic
Concepts: Analyze how scarcity
and artificial shortages force
individuals, organizations,
communities, and governments
to make choices and incur
opportunity costs. Analyze how
the decisions of individuals,
organizations, communities, and
governments affect economic
equity and efficiency.

2E8D0E676EC94F0F99F1AD163E37DFF6.description:
Evaluate the impact of different economic systems on
socioeconomic development.

574578625B6743BABB9C77BD04B1FAF9.description:
Economic Inquiry: Use
economic models and reasoning
and data analysis to construct an
argument and propose a solution
related to an economic question.
Evaluate the impact of the
proposed solution on various
communities that would be
affected.

F7BBEA549C554F1987EAD97AA38B9AE3.description:
Compare the values, principles and rights in tribal constitutions
with the U.S. Constitution.

833106E619FF4548BFC903BE41E2E18B.description:
Tribal Nations: Evaluate the
unique political status, trust
relationships and governing
structures of sovereign Tribal
Nations and the United States.

59B8937CC8674E02A609B7E30EE41F87.description:
Explain why governments belong to different types of alliances
and international organizations, and describe how they
influence public policy.

783F677D1C7745688684517A05CE793E.description:
Public Policy: Analyze how
public policy is shaped by
governmental and nongovernmental institutions.
Analyze how people and
communities take action to solve
problems and shape public policy.

6A8301F7FC4F474395A0A4F2B345EB1C.description:
Compare and contrast the structures, foundations, powers,
alliances and limitations of the United States government with
the United Nations.

5D8B5C7EE4BB429DBED19B2845549AFC.description:
Governmental Institutions and
Political Processes: Explain and
evaluate processes, rules and
laws of United States
governmental institutions at
local, state and federal levels and
within Tribal Nations.

61C728EA7DDA4E74A1910838180FAF6C.description:
Analyze the role of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights
(UDHR) and non-governmental organizations in how human
rights have been addressed in different countries.

30EC8020D88741DF8CD502D83CDFE7DE.description:
Rights and Responsibilities:
Explain and evaluate rights,
duties and responsibilities in
democratic society.

90BF886BC6DD4B769BD212868257703A.description:
Identify and evaluate democratic principles in different world
constitutions. Compare and contrast various systems of
government and their methods of maintaining order and/or
control.

746E93543EEC407080B988E381543C47.description:
Democratic Values and
Principles: Explain democratic
values and principles that guide
governments, societies and
communities. Analyze the
tensions within the United States
constitutional government.

50B77473B88F47A5980C8FD9790D7774.description:
Participate in civil discourse on contemporary global issues in
the world and evaluate arguments including identifying pros
and cons.

2AF7A08BEE4B41AD9A856AC683D57269.description:
Civic Skills: Apply civic
reasoning and demonstrate civic
skills for the purpose of informed
and engaged lifelong civic
participation.
